newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Gulf Coast features plethora of foreign crude.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Gulf Coast features plethora of foreign crude.

text.p: The U.S. Gulf Coast featured a plethora of foreign crudes on Tuesday, offering refiners a wide selection as they gear up for the summer driving season, trade sources said.

North Sea Brent remained elusive despite continuing talk. Koch Oil was the player last heard offering Brent at May West Texas Intermediate/Cushing minus 65 cents a barrel. Bids were seen around minus 93 cents.

The U.S. company was heard to have cancelled a vessel that was on subjects, however, after failing to acquire the Brents from British Petroleum, which holds 10 cargoes of unsold April Brent, traders said.
Other North Sea crudes have moved more swiftly. Late last week, a Norwegian company sold an Oseberg cargo to Fina at May WTI minus 85 cents for April 25-30 delivery.
Earlier, the same company sold a Troll cargo to Midwest refiner Farmland at an undisclosed price, traders said.
Oseberg and Gullfaks are now on offer at May WTI minus $1.00 and minus 90 cents, respectively, for end-April or early May arrival on the Gulf Coast.

The May spread between West Texas Intermediate/Cushing and Brent was around $1.30-35 a barrel Tuesday afternoon, a level deemed as "wide open" for transatlantic trade in light of the depressed price of dated Brent.
A wet Brent cargo for April 7-9 was sold on Tuesday at May Brent minus 94 cents, up two cents from a deal on Monday but six cents weaker than last Thursday's values, traders said.
In Latin America, Chile's state-owned oil company Empresa Nacional del Petroleo (ENAP) is seeking to buy 960,000 barrels of crude oil for delivery May 20.
The tender will be awarded on April 3.
In its last purchase tender before Easter, ENAP bought 950,000 barrels of Nigerian Forcados and 360,000 barrels of Ecuadoran Oriente for delivery April 10-14.
Elsewhere, Colombian Cusiana, a gasoline-rich grade, was heard offered at June WTI minus $1.35 fob for May 7-11 loading.
Market talk, however, suggested the crude could plummet to as low as a $1.70 discount.
Cusiana, like other short-haul barrels, has come under sharp pressure from plentiful transatlantic supplies.
